intro: Grammitis stuebelii, commonly known as the Stuebel's spikemoss, is a member of the family Huperjaniaceae and is native to tropical regions of South America. It is a small, evergreen fern that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices. The plant features a dense, compact rosette of leaves that are usually dark green and covered in a fine, waxy coating. Its spore-producing structures, called sporangia, are clustered on the underside of the leaves, a characteristic feature of the spore-bearing plants. Grammitis stuebelii plays an important ecological role in its habitat by contributing to soil stabilization and providing microhabitat for various invertebrates.
